results.title: Mining in Australia: the the story of copper
results.creator_credit: Brian Merrett and Tasmanian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: Describes copper mining at Mt Lyell in Tasmania. Shows blasting, crushing of the ore, removal of iron particles, grinding the ore to powder, silo stores, blast furnace, removal of slag, the converter, and finally the cathode copper.

results.title: Mining for copper
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and J. Arthur Rank
results.brief_description: An account of mining and refining of copper in Northern Rhodesia; the geography of the country; details of structure of the mines; operation of the mine; processes for the extraction of copper from ore including the crushing, smelting, refining and final casting into commercial moulds for shipment.

results.title: Mining employment opportunities
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Don Harley and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A record of a visit by seven Aboriginal community leaders from the Northern Territory, to three mining centres, Mount Isa, Mary Kathleen and Bougainville Copper. This enabled them to see how a mining operation works and what kinds of jobs exist in the mines.

results.title: Mining centre: Johannesburg
results.creator_credit: S.G. Fergusson, Donald Swanson and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: A survey of the mining city of Johannesburg and a short explanation on the nature of gold bearing reefs. A map of Africa shows the mineral areas and an animated diagram of the Witwatersrand explains how the gold reefs lie. The development of the Rand and of Johannesburg is outlined in brief historic sequences and its relation to the growth of mining explained.

results.title: Mining
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
A detailed statement of Australia’s massive mining developments in the eighties - tin, coal, bauxite, iron ore as well as the production of the more rare metals such as gold, silver and uranium. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Miniature Magic
results.brief_description: Some of the biggest set pieces in film and TV are actually the smallest. Big scenes can be too complicated or expensive to film with huge, life-size sets, so production teams create detailed miniatures and use camera tricks to make them appear as the real thing.

constellations_primary.name: Sci-fi miniatures
constellations_primary.description: As filmmaking technologies have changed and evolved over the decades, much like audiences, miniatures have endured as one of the most effective film special effects.

results.description:
Some of the biggest set pieces in film and TV are actually the smallest. Sometimes big scenes are too complicated or expensive to film with huge, life-size sets so production teams create detailed miniatures of locations and settings, and then use camera techniques to trick the audience into thinking they’re seeing the real thing.

This model represents that approach and references schlocky 1950s sci-fi films, like It Came From Outer Space (1953) and The War of the Worlds (1953), which often used miniatures for their out-of-this-world plots. Miniatures have since been used in blockbusters like Star Wars (1977), Alien (1979) and Batman (1989). Often, they’re created just to be destroyed – like the White House in Roland Emmerich’s Independence Day (1996).
description_for_label:

Sometimes big scenes are too complicated or expensive to film with huge, life-size sets so production teams create detailed miniatures of locations and settings, and then use camera techniques to trick the audience into thinking they’re seeing the real thing.

This model represents that approach and references schlocky 1950s sci-fi films, like It Came From Outer Space (1953) and The War of the Worlds (1953), which often used miniatures for their out-of-this-world plots. Miniatures have since been used in blockbusters like Star Wars (1977), Alien (1979) and Batman (1989). Often, they’re created just to be destroyed – like the White House in Roland Emmerich’s Independence Day (1996).

results.title: Mini movie makers
results.brief_description: Children at the Henry Street Settlement in New York exhibit the efforts of their film club. Two processes were employed: making a film with and without a camera. Firstly, they drew directly on clear film with magic markers, then used paper cutout puppets. Voice-over comments by the children describe their techniques.

results.creator_credit: Shuji Yamamoto, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television and Film Australia

results.title: Mini Dragons
results.creator_credit: Richard Carey, INCA, Nihon Hoso Kyokai and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A series which look at the new economic powers of the Asian region - Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore. Through the eyes of disparate individuals from each country the programs look at the historical context of the mini dragons’ current success and the unique problems they face in their bid to retain economic leadership in the area.
